authors: Yanping Zhao; Man Yu; Senlin Wu; Chan He

title: Vector valued invariant means, complementability and almost constrained subspaces
abstract: Abstract In this paper we will study a connection between some generalization of AC -subspaces, vector valued invariant $$\lambda $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>λ</mml:mi> </mml:math> -means and $$\lambda $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>λ</mml:mi> </mml:math> -complementability.

title: Exponential polynomials and the sine addition law on magmas
abstract: For any set X we let F(X) denote the complex vector space of functions f: X→ C . Let X= S be a magma, and let V be a subspace of F(S) , which is invariant under left or right translations. It is known for an abelian group S that if p1χ1, ⋯ , pnχn∈ F(S) are nonzero exponential polynomials with distinct exponentials χ1, ⋯ , χn then p1χ1+ ⋯ + pnχn∈ V⇒ p1χ1, ⋯ , pnχn∈ V and χ1, ⋯ , χn∈ V . We extend this to magmas. Our results imply that any exponential polynomial solution f∈ F(S) of f(xy) = f(x) χ(y) + χ(x) f(y) where χ∈ F(S) is an exponential, has the form f= aχ where a∈ F(S) is additive, even when χ has zeros.

title: A Pexider equation containing the aritmetic mean
abstract: Abstract In this paper we determine the solutions $$(\varphi ,f_1,f_2)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of the Pexider functional equation $$\begin{aligned} \varphi \Big (\frac{x+y}{2}\Big )\big (f_1(x)-f_2(y)\big )=0,\qquad (x,y)\in I_1\times I_2, \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>×</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> where $$I_1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> and $$I_2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> are nonempty open subintervals. Special cases of the above equation regularly arise in problems with two-variable means. We show that, under a rather weak regularity condition, the coordinate-functions of a typical solution of the equation are constant over several subintervals of their domain. The regularity condition in question will be that the set of zeros of $$\varphi $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> </mml:math> is closed. We also discuss particular solutions where this condition is not met.

title: Isometry groups of six-dimensional nilmanifolds
abstract: Abstract We determine the 6-dimensional nilpotent metric Lie algebras such that the Lie algebra $${\mathfrak {n}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:math> has a descending series of ideals invariant under all automorphisms of $${\mathfrak {n}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:math> and the dimension of the consecutive members of the series decreases by one. We call them metric Lie algebras having a framing determined by ideals. We classify the isometry equivalence classes and determine the isometry groups of connected and simply connected Riemannian nilmanifolds on 6-dimensional nilpotent Lie groups having a Lie algebra $${\mathfrak {n}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:math> as their Lie algebra.

title: A note on iterated maps of the unit sphere
Some characterizations of the disc by properties of isoptic triangles
authors: Rafael I. Ayala-Figueroa; Iván González-García; Jesús Jerónimo-Castro; Francisco G. Jimenez-Lopez

title: Characterization of the Bernoulli polynomials via the Raabe functional equation
Proof of a conjecture due to Chu on Gosper-type sums
Minimal codewords in Norm-Trace codes
authors: Daniele Bartoli; Matteo Bonini; Marco Timpanella
abstract: In this paper, we consider the affine variety codes obtained evaluating the polynomials by=a kx k+…+a 1x+a 0, b,a i∈Fq r, at the affine Fq r-rational points of the Norm-Trace curve. In particular, we investigate the weight distribution and the set of minimal codewords. Our approach, which uses tools of algebraic geometry, is based on the study of the absolute irreducibility of certain algebraic varieties.

title: A Tverberg type theorem for staircase convexity
Paired-domination game played on paths
authors: Aaron D. Gray; Michael A. Henning

title: The Artin-Hasse series and Laguerre polynomials modulo a prime
abstract: Abstract For an odd prime p , let $${{\,\textrm{E}\,}}_{p}(X)=\sum _{n=0}^{\infty } a_{n}X^{n}\in {\mathbb {F}}_p[[X]]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mspace/> <mml:mtext>E</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace/> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mo>∑</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> denote the reduction modulo p of the Artin-Hasse exponential series. It is known that there exists a series $$G(X^p)\in {\mathbb {F}}_{p}[[X]]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , such that $$L_{p-1}^{(-T(X))}(X)={{\,\textrm{E}\,}}_{p}(X)\cdot G(X^p)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mi>L</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>T</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:msubsup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mspace/> <mml:mtext>E</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace/> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>·</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , where $$T(X)=\sum _{i=1}^{\infty }X^{p^{i}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>T</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mo>∑</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and $$L_{p-1}^{(\alpha )}(X)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mi>L</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>α</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:msubsup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> denotes the (generalized) Laguerre polynomial of degree $$p-1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . We prove that $$G(X^p)=\sum _{n=0}^{\infty }(-1)^n a_{np}X^{np}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mo>∑</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>np</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:msub> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>np</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , and show that it satisfies $$ G(X^p)\,G(-X^p)\,T(X)=X^p. $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mspace/> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mspace/> <mml:mi>T</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>.</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math>

title: Weighted Ingham-type inequalities via the positivity of quadratic polynomials
authors: Ionel Rovenţa; Laurenţiu Emanuel Temereancă; Mihai Adrian Tudor

title: On sets related to integer partitions with quasi-required elements and disallowed elements
authors: Aureliano M. Robles-Pérez; J. C. Rosales
abstract: Abstract Given a set A of non-negative integers and a set B of positive integers, we are interested in computing all sets C (of positive integers) that are minimal in the family of sets K (of positive integers) such that ( i ) K contains no elements generated by non-negative integer linear combinations of elements in A and ( ii ) for any partition of an element in B there is at least one summand that belongs to K . To solve this question, we translate it into a numerical semigroups problem.

title: Prefixes of bargraph paths
abstract: Abstract We extend the notion of bargraphs as first quadrant, semi-perimeter defined lattice paths to that of a bargraph prefix where we relax the bargraph defining parameters and allow the bargraph to extend into negative territory. A bargraph prefix is any initial section of a bargraph. Generating functions for the prefixes which separately track the number of up, down and horizontal steps are found. The asymptotics for the average height of the last prefix step in the different bargraph extensions is given.

title: Extreme area and perimeter bisectors in a triangle
Remarks on a linearization of Koopmans recursion
abstract: Abstract Let X be a metric space and $$U:X^{\infty }\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be a continuous function satisfying the Koopmans recursion $$U(x_0,x_1,x_2,\ldots )=\varphi (x_0, U(x_1,x_2,\ldots )),$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> where $$\varphi :X\times I \rightarrow I$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>×</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is a continuous function and I is an interval. Denote by $$\succeq $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mo>⪰</mml:mo> </mml:math> a preference relation defined on the product $$X^{\infty }$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> represented by a function $$U:X^{\infty }\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , called a utility function, that means $$(x_0,x_1,\ldots )\succeq (y_0,y_1,\ldots )\Leftrightarrow U(x_0,x_1,\ldots )\ge U(y_0,y_1,\ldots )$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>⪰</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>⇔</mml:mo> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . We consider a problem when the preference relation $$\succeq $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mo>⪰</mml:mo> </mml:math> can be represented by another utility function V satisfying the affine recursion $$V(x_0,x_1,x_2,\ldots ) = \alpha (x_0)V(x_1,x_2,\ldots )+ \beta (x_0)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>V</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>α</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>V</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>β</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . Under suitable assumptions on relation $$\succeq $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mo>⪰</mml:mo> </mml:math> we determine the form of the functions $$\varphi $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> </mml:math> defining the utility functions possessing the above property. The problem is reduced to solving a system of simultaneous functional equations. The subject is strictly connected to a problem of preference in economics. In this note we extend the results obtained in Zdun (Aequ Math 94, 2020).

title: Zero utility principles coinciding on binary risks
abstract: Abstract It is known that the zero utility principle under Cumulative Prospect Theory can be uniquely extended from the family of all ternary risks. On the other hand, the extension from the family of all binary risks need not be unique. We establish a characterization of those zero utility principles which coincide on the family of binary risks. The characterization is expressed in terms of relations between the systems of generators of the principles.

title: On the set of orthogonally additive functions with orthogonally additive second iterate
abstract: Let E be a real inner product space of dimension at least 2. We show that both the set of all orthogonally additive functions mapping E into E having orthogonally additive second iterate and its complement are dense in the space of all orthogonally additive functions from E into E with the Tychonoff topology.

title: New characterizations of the Takagi function via functional equations
abstract: We provide two new characterizations of the Takagi function as the unique bounded solution of some systems of two functional equations. The results are independent of those obtained by Kairies (Wyż Szkoł Ped Krakow Rocznik Nauk Dydakt Prace Mat 196:73–82, 1998), Kairies (Aequ Math 53:207–241, 1997), Kairies (Aequ Math 58:183–191, 1999) and Kairies et al. (Rad Mat 4:361–374, 1989; Errata, Rad Mat 5:179–180, 1989).

title: Generalization of Heron’s and Brahmagupta’s equalities to any cyclic polygon
abstract: Abstract It is well known that Heron’s equality provides an explicit formula for the area of a triangle, as a symmetric function of the lengths of its edges. It has been extended by Brahmagupta to quadrilaterals inscribed in a circle (cyclic quadrilaterals). A natural problem is trying to further generalize the result to cyclic polygons with a larger number of edges. Surprisingly, this has proved to be far from simple, and no explicit solutions exist for cyclic polygons having $$n>4$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>></mml:mo> <mml:mn>4</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> edges. In this paper we investigate such a problem by following a new and elementary approach, based on the idea that the simple geometry underlying Heron’s and Brahmagupta’s equalities hides the real players of the game. In details, we propose to focus on the dissection of the edges determined by the incircles of a suitable triangulation of the cyclic polygon, showing that this approach leads to an explicit formula for the area as a symmetric function of the lengths of these segments. We also show that such a symmetry can be rediscovered in Heron’s and Brahmagupta’s results, which consequently represent special cases of the provided general equality.

Some remarks on the stability of the Cauchy equation and completeness
abstract: Abstract It was proved in Forti and Schwaiger (C R Math Acad Sci Soc R Can 11(6):215–220, 1989), Schwaiger (Aequ Math 35:120–121, 1988) and with different methods in Schwaiger (Developments in functional equations and related topics. Selected papers based on the presentations at the 16th international conference on functional equations and inequalities, ICFEI, Bȩdlewo, Poland, May 17–23, 2015, Springer, Cham, pp 275–295, 2017) that under the assumption that every function defined on suitable abelian semigroups with values in a normed space such that the norm of its Cauchy difference is bounded by a constant (function) is close to some additive function, i.e., the norm of the difference between the given function and that additive function is also bounded by a constant, the normed space must necessarily be complete. By Schwaiger (Ann Math Sil 34:151–163, 2020) this is also true in the non-archimedean case. Here we discuss the situation when the bound is a suitable non-constant function.

title: Moment functions and exponential monomials on commutative hypergroups
authors: Żywilla Fechner; Eszter Gselmann; László Székelyhidi
abstract: Abstract The purpose of this paper is to prove that if on a commutative hypergroup an exponential monomial has the property that the linear subspace of all sine functions in its variety is one dimensional, then this exponential monomial is a linear combination of generalized moment functions.

title: When are maps preserving semi-inner products linear?
abstract: Abstract We observe that every map between finite-dimensional normed spaces of the same dimension that respects fixed semi-inner products must be automatically a linear isometry. Moreover, we construct a uniformly smooth renorming of the Hilbert space $$\ell _2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ℓ</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> and a continuous injection acting thereon that respects the semi-inner products, yet it is non-linear. This demonstrates that there is no immediate extension of the former result to infinite dimensions, even under an extra assumption of uniform smoothness.

title: Quadratic ellipsoids in Minkowski geometries
abstract: Abstract A Minkowski plane is Euclidean if and only if at least one ellipse is a quadric. We discuss the higher dimensional consequences too.

title: Some results for conjugate equations
On the special form of integral convolution type inequality due to Walter and Weckesser
abstract: Walter and Weckesser’s result (Aequationes Math 46:212–219, 1993), extending the Bushell–Okrasiński convolution type inequality (Bushell and Okrasiński in J Lond Math Soc (2) 41:503–510, 1990), gave some general conditions on the functions $$k:\left[ 0,d\right) \rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ and $$g:\left[ 0,\infty \right) \rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ under which, for every increasing function f : $$\left[ 0,d\right) \rightarrow \left[ 0,\infty \right) $$ , the inequality $$\begin{aligned} \int _{0}^{x}k\left( x-s\right) g\left( f\left( s\right) \right) ds\le g\left( \int _{0}^{x}f\left( s\right) ds\right) ,\quad x\in \left( 0,d\right) , \end{aligned}$$ is satisfied. Applying the result on a simultaneous system of functional inequalities, we prove that if $$d>1,$$ then, in general, both k and g must be power functions.

Functional equations for exponential polynomials
abstract: The aim of the present paper is to describe some properties of functions with finite dimensional difference spaces by means of spectral analysis and spectral synthesis. We are going to apply these results to a version of a Levi-Civita functional equation, which has been recently studied by J. M. Almira and E. Shulman.

title: On a functional equation related to a problem of G. Derfel
abstract: Two years ago, during the 21st European Conference on Iteration Theory, Gregory Derfel asked: “Does there exist a non-trivial bounded continuous solution of the equation $$2f(x) = f(x-1) + f(-2x)$$ ?” He repeated the question during the 55th International Symposium on Functional Equations. In this paper we present a partial solution of a more general problem, connected to the functional equation $$f(x) = M \big ( f(x+t_{1}), f(x + t_{2} ),\ldots , f(x + t_{n-1} ), \,f(ax) \big ),$$ where $$n \in \mathbb {N}, \,t_{1},t_{2},\ldots ,t_{n-1} \in \mathbb {R} {\setminus } \{ 0\}, \,a \in (-\infty , 0)$$ and M is a given function in n variables satisfying some additional properties. In particular, M can be a weighted quasi-arithmetic mean in n variables.

title: A characterization of additive iterative roots of identity with respect to invariant subspaces
abstract: Let $$\mathbb {K}$$ be an extension of the field $$\mathbb {Q}$$ of rational numbers. We prove an algebraic characterization of the additive iterative roots of identity defined on a vector space X over the field $$\mathbb {K}$$ which save a Hamel basis of X (a basis of X over $$\mathbb {Q}$$ ). The method is based on a canonical decomposition theorem.

title: Grüss type and related integral inequalities in probability spaces
On meaningful transformation equations
abstract: The meaningfulness condition, applied to scientific or geometric laws, requires that the mathematical form of an equation does not change when we change the units of its ratio scale variables. Suitably formalized, this condition considerably limits the possible form of a law. In this paper, we give five new examples of such restricted representations. We use the meaningfulness condition on the five transformation equations displayed in the left column of the table below, in which x, y, z, u and v are real numbers and F, K, G, H, M and N are real valued functions. We show that under relatively weak general conditions (such as continuity, symmetry, monotonicity, homogeneity), each transformation equation must have, up to some real constants, the representation in the right column.

title: Generalized convex functions on normal decomposition systems
Almost t-complementary uniform hypergraphs
Remarks on (F, t)-convex functions
abstract: In this work we discuss counterparts of some classical results connected with convex functions for a new class of functions, namely for (F, t)-convex functions. We obtain Bernstein–Doetsch, Ostrowski and Sirpiński type theorems for them. A version of a Kuhn type result is also presented.

title: Complexity in iteration of polynomials
Products of graceful bipartite graphs
Stochastic processes generating Schur-convex sums
abstract: The notion of Schur-convex stochastic processes is introduced and processes generating Schur-convex sums are investigated. Some inequalities connected with convex stochastic processes are obtained. A counterpart of the result of Ng stating that a stochastic process generates Schur-convex sums if and only if it is Wright-convex is proved.

title: Alienation and stability of Jensen’s and other functional equations
Means of Cauchy’s difference type
Global centers of a family of cubic systems
abstract: Abstract Consider the family of polynomial differential systems of degree 3, or simply cubic systems $$ x' = y, \quad y' = -x + a_1 x^2 + a_2 xy + a_3 y^2 + a_4 x^3 + a_5 x^2 y + a_6 xy^2 + a_7 y^3, $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>′</mml:mo> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mspace/> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>′</mml:mo> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mn>4</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mn>5</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mn>6</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mn>7</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> in the plane $$\mathbb {R}^2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> </mml:math> . An equilibrium point $$(x_0,y_0)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of a planar differential system is a center if there is a neighborhood $$\mathcal {U}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> </mml:math> of $$(x_0,y_0)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> such that $$\mathcal {U} \backslash \{(x_0,y_0)\}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>U</mml:mi> <mml:mo>\</mml:mo> <mml:mo>{</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>}</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is filled with periodic orbits. When $$\mathbb {R}^2\setminus \{(x_0,y_0)\}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>\</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>{</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>}</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is filled with periodic orbits, then the center is a global center . For this family of cubic systems Lloyd and Pearson characterized in Lloyd and Pearson (Comput Math Appl 60:2797–2805, 2010) when the origin of coordinates is a center. We classify which of these centers are global centers.

title: On some classes of multiplicative functions
abstract: Abstract An arithmetical function f is multiplicative if $$f(1)=1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and $$f(mn)=f(m)f(n)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>m</mml:mi> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>m</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> whenever m and n are coprime. We study connections between certain subclasses of multiplicative functions, such as strongly multiplicative functions, over-multiplicative functions and totients. It appears, among others, that the over-multiplicative functions are exactly same as the totients and the strongly multiplicative functions are exactly same as the so-called level totients. All these functions satisfy nice arithmetical identities which are recursive in character.

title: A characterization of the Euclidean ball via antipodal points
Generalizing the concept of bounded variation
abstract: Abstract Let $$[a,b]\subseteq \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>b</mml:mi> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> <mml:mo>⊆</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be a non-empty and non singleton closed interval and $$P=\{a=x_0<\cdots <x_n=b\}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mo>{</mml:mo> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>b</mml:mi> <mml:mo>}</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is a partition of it. Then $$f:I\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is said to be a function of r -bounded variation, if the expression $$\sum \nolimits ^{n}_{i=1}|f(x_i)-f(x_{i-1})|^{r}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mo>∑</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>|</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>|</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is bounded for all possible partitions like P . One of the main results of the paper deals with the generalization of the classical Jordan decomposition theorem. We establish that for $$r\in ]0,1]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , a function of r -bounded variation can be written as the difference of two monotone functions. While for $$r>1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mo>></mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , under minimal assumptions such a function can be treated as an approximately monotone function which can be closely approximated by a nondecreasing majorant. We also prove that for $$0<r_1<r_2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , the function class of $$r_1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> -bounded variation is contained in the class of functions satisfying $$r_2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> -bounded variations. We go through approximately monotone functions and present a possible decomposition for $$f:I(\subseteq \mathbb {R}_+)\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>⊆</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> satisfying the functional inequality $$f(x)\le f(x)+(y-x)^{p}\quad (x,y\in I \text{ with } x<y \text{ and } p\in ]0,1[ ).$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>with</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>and</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>.</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> A generalized structural study has also been done in that specific section. On the other hand, for $$\ell [a,b]\ge d$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>ℓ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>b</mml:mi> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , a function satisfying the following monotonic condition under the given assumption will be termed as d -periodically increasing $$f(x)\le f(y)\quad \text{ for } \text{ all }\quad x,y\in I\quad \text{ with }\quad y-x\ge d.$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>for</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>all</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>with</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> <mml:mo>.</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> We establish that in a compact interval any function satisfying d -bounded variation can be decomposed as the difference of a monotone and a d -periodically increasing function. The core details related to past results, motivation, structure of each and every section are thoroughly discussed below.

title: Set valued pexiderized quadratic functional equation
authors: Elham Mohammadi; Abbas Najati; Kazimierz Nikodem

title: On when the union of two algebraic sets is algebraic
authors: Erhard Aichinger; Mike Behrisch; Bernardo Rossi

title: Rotations on the triangular grid: angles of changes of the neighborhood motion map
authors: Müge Saadetoğlu; Benedek Nagy; Aydın Avkan

title: Equalities for mixed operations of Moore–Penrose and group inverses of a matrix
Skew Dyck paths with air pockets
authors: Jean-Luc Baril; Rémi Maréchal; Helmut Prodinger

title: On double Roman domination problem for several graph classes
authors: Tatjana Zec; Dragan Matić; Marko Djukanović

title: A note on ideal C$$^*$$-completions and amenability
abstract: Abstract For a discrete group G , we consider certain ideals $$\mathcal {I}\subset c_0(G)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>c</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of sequences with prescribed rate of convergence to zero. We show that the equality between the full group C $$^*$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow/> <mml:mo>∗</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> -algebra of G and the C $$^*$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow/> <mml:mo>∗</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> -completion $$\textrm{C}^*_{\mathcal {I}}(G)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mtext>C</mml:mtext> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∗</mml:mo> </mml:msubsup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> in the sense of Brown and Guentner (Bull. London Math. Soc. 45:1181–1193, 2013) implies that G is amenable.

title: Behavior of convex integrand at a d-apex of its Wulff shape and approximation of spherical bodies of constant width
The Rhodes semilattice of a biased graph
Shannon’s entropy and its bounds for some a priori known equiprobable states
abstract: Abstract It is known that Shannon’s entropy is nonnegative and its maximum value is reached for equiprobable events. Adding or removing impossible events does not affect Shannon’s entropy. However, if we increase the number of events and consider not necessarily all of them equiprobable, but at least as many of them as the initial number of equiprobable events, how does Shannon’s entropy change? We study the lower bound of the interval where the probability value of the a priori assumed equiprobable states must belong when the entropy increases.

title: A note on homotopy extension KKM type maps
Alienation of the quadratic, exponential and d’Alembert functional equations
abstract: Abstract Let $$(S,+,0)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be a commutative monoid, $$\sigma :S\rightarrow S$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>σ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be an endomorphism with $$\sigma ^2=id$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>σ</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and let K be a field of characteristic different from 2. We study the solutions $$f,g,h:S\rightarrow K$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>h</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>K</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of the Pexider type functional equation $$\begin{aligned} f(x+y)+f(x+\sigma y)+g(x+y)=2f(x)+2f(y)+g(x)g(y) \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>σ</mml:mi> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> resulting from summing up the well known quadratic and exponential functional equations side by side. We show that under some additional assumptions the above equation forces f and g to split back into the system of two equations $$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}f(x+y)+f(x+\sigma y)=2f(x)+2f(y)\\ g(x+y)=g(x)g(y)\end{array}\right. \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>σ</mml:mi> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:mrow/> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:mfenced> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for all $$x,y\in S$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> (alienation phenomenon). We also consider an analogous problem for the quadratic and d’Alembert functional equations as well as for the quadratic, exponential and d’Alembert functional equations.

title: On evolutes of curves in the isotropic plane
Hyers–Ulam stability of integral equations with infinite delay
abstract: Abstract Integral equations with infinite delay are considered as functional equations in a Banach space. Two types of Hyers–Ulam stability criteria are established. First, it is shown that a linear autonomous equation is Hyers–Ulam stable if and only if it has no characteristic value with zero real part. Second, it is proved that the Hyers–Ulam stability of a linear autonomous equation is preserved under sufficiently small nonlinear perturbations. The proofs are based on a recently developed decomposition theory of linear integral equations with infinite delay.

title: Operators with a non-trivial closed invariant affine subspace
abstract: Abstract We are concerned with the question of the existence of an invariant proper affine subspace for an operator A on a complex Banach space. It turns out that the presence of the number 1 in the spectrum of A or in the spectrum of its adjoint operator $$A^*$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∗</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> is crucial. For instance, an algebraic operator has an invariant proper affine subspace if and only if 1 is its eigenvalue. For an arbitrary operator A , we show that it has an invariant proper hyperplane if and only if 1 is an eigenvalue of $$A^*$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∗</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> . If A is a power bounded operator, then every invariant proper affine subspace is contained in an invariant proper hyperplane, moreover, A has a non-trivial invariant cone.

title: Casting light on integer compositions
authors: Aubrey Blecher; Arnold Knopfmacher; Michael Mays
abstract: Abstract Integer compositions of n are viewed as bargraphs with n circular nodes or square cells in which the i th part of the composition $$x_i$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:math> is given by the i th column of the bargraph with $$x_i$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:math> nodes or cells. The sun is at infinity in the north west of our two dimensional model and each node/cell may or may not be lit depending on whether it stands in the shadow cast by another node/cell to its left. We study the number of lit nodes in an integer composition of n and later we modify this to yield the number of lit square cells. We then count the number of columns being lit which leads naturally to those cases where only the first column is lit. We prove the theorem that the generating function for the latter is the same as the generating function for compositions in which the first part is strictly smallest. This theorem has interesting q -series identities as corollaries which allow us to deduce in a simple way the asymptotics for both the number of lit nodes and columns as $$n \rightarrow \infty $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> .

title: n-gon centers and central lines
authors: Marta Farré Puiggalí; Luis Felipe Prieto–Martínez

title: Path factors in bipartite graphs from size or spectral radius
On spectral irregularity of graphs
Another look at the Matkowski and Wesołowski problem yielding a new class of solutions
abstract: Abstract The following MW-problem was posed independently by Janusz Matkowski and Jacek Wesołowski in different forms in 1985 and 2009, respectively: Are there increasing and continuous functions $$\varphi :[0,1]\rightarrow [0,1]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , distinct from the identity on [0, 1], such that $$\varphi (0)=0$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , $$\varphi (1)=1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and $$\varphi (x)=\varphi (\frac{x}{2})+\varphi (\frac{x+1}{2})-\varphi (\frac{1}{2})$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for every $$x\in [0,1]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> ? By now, it is known that each of the de Rham functions $$R_p$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:math> , where $$p\in (0,1)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , is a solution of the MW-problem, and for any Borel probability measure $$\mu $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>μ</mml:mi> </mml:math> concentrated on (0, 1) the formula $$\phi _\mu (x)=\int _{(0,1)}R_p(x)\, d\mu (p)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ϕ</mml:mi> <mml:mi>μ</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mo>∫</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:msub> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mspace/> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> <mml:mi>μ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> defines a solution $$\phi _\mu :[0,1]\rightarrow [0,1]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ϕ</mml:mi> <mml:mi>μ</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of this problem as well. In this paper, we give a new family of solutions of the MW-problem consisting of Cantor-type functions. We also prove that there are strictly increasing solutions of the MW-problem that are not of the above integral form with any Borel probability measure $$\mu $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>μ</mml:mi> </mml:math> .

title: Some new minimax inequalities for centered convex bodies
authors: Horst Martini; Zokhrab Mustafaev; Sakhavet M. Zarbaliev
abstract: Abstract The purpose of this manuscript is to derive some new minimax inequalities for centered convex bodies in $${\mathbb {R}}^{d}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> . As consequences, new characterizations of ellipsoids will be established as well. Some open problems related to the Busemann-Petty list of problems will also be discussed.

abstract: Abstract For every positive integer, we introduce an adjacency in the digital space $${\mathbb {Z}}^3$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:msup> </mml:math> . Connectedness in the graph obtained is then used to define and study digital Jordan surfaces. The surfaces are acquired as polyhedral surfaces bounding the digital polyhedra that can be face-to-face tiled with digital cubes, triangular prisms, square pyramids, and tetrahedra.

title: Maker-Breaker resolving game played on corona products of graphs
authors: Tijo James; Sandi Klavžar; Dorota Kuziak; Savitha K.S.; Ambat Vijayakumar
abstract: Abstract The Maker-Breaker resolving game is a game played on a graph G by Resolver and Spoiler. The players taking turns alternately in which each player selects a not yet played vertex of G . The goal of Resolver is to select all the vertices in a resolving set of G , while that of Spoiler is to prevent this from happening. The outcome o ( G ) of the game played is one of $$\mathcal {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:math> , $$\mathcal {S}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> </mml:math> , and $$\mathcal {N}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:math> , where $$o(G)=\mathcal {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> (resp. $$o(G)=\mathcal {S}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> ), if Resolver (resp. Spoiler) has a winning strategy no matter who starts the game, and $$o(G)=\mathcal {N}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , if the first player has a winning strategy. In this paper, the game is investigated on corona products $$G\odot H$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊙</mml:mo> <mml:mi>H</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of graphs G and H . It is proved that if $$o(H)\in \{\mathcal {N}, \mathcal {S}\}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>H</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mo>{</mml:mo> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> <mml:mo>}</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , then $$o(G\odot H) = \mathcal {S}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊙</mml:mo> <mml:mi>H</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . No such result is possible under the assumption $$o(H) = \mathcal {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>H</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . It is proved that $$o(G\odot P_k) = \mathcal {S}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊙</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> if $$k=5$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>5</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , otherwise $$o(G\odot P_k) = \mathcal {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊙</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , and that $$o(G\odot C_k) = \mathcal {S}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊙</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> if $$k=3$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , otherwise $$o(G\odot C_k) = \mathcal {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>o</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊙</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . Several results are also given on corona products in which the second factor is of diameter at most 2.

title: A simple proof of the rationality of Takagi-like functions
authors: Yang‐Yang Chen; Nankun Hong; Hongyuan Yu

title: The 60th International Symposium on Functional Equations, Hotel Rewita, Kościelisko (Poland), June 9–15, 2024
Sparse groups need not be semisparse
abstract: Abstract In 1999 Michael Hartley showed that any abstract polytope can be constructed as a double coset poset, by means of a C-group $$\mathcal {W}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>W</mml:mi> </mml:math> and a subgroup $$N \le \mathcal {W}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>W</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . Subgroups $$N \le \mathcal {W}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>W</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> that give rise to abstract polytopes through such a construction are called sparse . If, further, the stabilizer of a base flag of the poset is precisely N , then N is said to be semisparse . In [4, Conjecture 5.2] Hartely conjectures that sparse groups are always semisparse. In this paper, we show that this conjecture is in fact false: there exist sparse groups that are not semisparse. In particular, we show that such groups are always obtained from non-faithful maniplexes that give rise to polytopes. Using this, we show that Hartely’s conjecture holds for rank 3, but we construct examples to disprove the conjecture for all ranks $$n\ge 4$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mn>4</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> .

abstract: Abstract Let P be a nonconstant selfmap of a set $$\mathcal {M}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>M</mml:mi></mml:math> . A sandwich-type theorem for generalized sub- P -periodic functions defined on $$\mathcal {M}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>M</mml:mi></mml:math> with values in a reflexive Banach space is proved. In particular, given functions $$f,g:\mathcal {M}\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mo>:</mml:mo><mml:mi>M</mml:mi><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi>R</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> , we obtain necessary and sufficient conditions for the existence of a generalized P -periodic function $$F:\mathcal {M}\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>F</mml:mi><mml:mo>:</mml:mo><mml:mi>M</mml:mi><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi>R</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> such that $$f\le F\le g$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mo>≤</mml:mo><mml:mi>F</mml:mi><mml:mo>≤</mml:mo><mml:mi>g</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> . The formula for F is given and its Lipschitz constant is discussed. Moreover the solvability of the functional equation $$f\circ p= r\circ f$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mo>∘</mml:mo><mml:mi>p</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mo>∘</mml:mo><mml:mi>f</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> with the help of a new sandwich method, is considered.

abstract: Abstract We observe that bisymmetry is in fact the assertion of the Fubini theorem and we describe the form of general bisymmetric operations on some function spaces.

Geometry on the lines of polar spine spaces
authors: Krzysztof Petelczyc; Krzysztof Prażmowski; Mariusz Żynel
abstract: Abstract The concept of spine geometry over a polar Grassmann space is introduced. We determine conditions under which the structure of lines together with a binary coplanarity relation is a sufficient system of primitive notions for polar spine spaces. These assumptions also allow to characterize polar spine spaces in terms of the binary relation of being in one pencil of lines.

title: On the Cauchy difference of functions bounded modulo $$\mathbb {Z}$$ on “large” sets
abstract: Abstract Let X be a real Polish vector space, $$D\subset X$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>D</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be a universally Baire non-Haar-meager set, and let $$f:X\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> satisfy $$f(x+y)-f(x)-f(y)\in \mathbb {Z}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for all $$x,y\in X$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and $$f(D)\subset (-\frac{1}{3},\frac{1}{3})+\mathbb {Z}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>D</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . We prove that there exists a unique linear functional $$L:X\rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>L</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> with $$f(x)-L(x)\in \mathbb {Z}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>L</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for $$x\in X$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and next we apply it to functionals which are orthogonally additive modulo $$\mathbb {Z}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> </mml:math> . These new results are topological counterparts to some results of Brzdȩk (Results Math 30:25–38, 1996) and also generalize (to some extent) his results.

title: Transitivity and sensitivity of iterated function systems via Furstenberg families
Undirecting membership in models of Anti-Foundation
abstract: Abstract It is known that, if we take a countable model of Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory ZFC and “undirect” the membership relation (that is, make a graph by joining x to y if either $$x\in y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> or $$y\in x$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> ), we obtain the Erdős–Rényi random graph. The crucial axiom in the proof of this is the Axiom of Foundation; so it is natural to wonder what happens if we delete this axiom, or replace it by an alternative (such as Aczel’s Anti-Foundation Axiom). The resulting graph may fail to be simple; it may have loops (if $$x\in x$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for some x ) or multiple edges (if $$x\in y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and $$y\in x$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for some distinct x , y ). We show that, in ZFA, if we keep the loops and ignore the multiple edges, we obtain the “random loopy graph” (which is $$\aleph _0$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ℵ</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> -categorical and homogeneous), but if we keep multiple edges, the resulting graph is not $$\aleph _0$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ℵ</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> -categorical, but has infinitely many 1-types. Moreover, if we keep only loops and double edges and discard single edges, the resulting graph contains countably many connected components isomorphic to any given finite connected graph with loops.

title: On polyhedral graphs and their complements
abstract: We find all polyhedral graphs such that their complements are still polyhedral. These turn out to be all self-complementary.

title: On optimal inequalities between three-point quadratures
abstract: Abstract We examine the family of all (at most) three-point symmetric quadratures on $$[-1,1]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> which are exact on polynomials of order 3 to find all possible inequalities between them in the class of 3-convex functions. Next we optimise them by using convex combinations of the quadratures considered. We find the optimal quadrature and use it to construct the adaptive method of approximate integration. An effective method to estimate the error of this method is also given. It needs a considerably fewer number of subdivisions of the interval of integration than the classical adaptive methods as well as the method developed by the second-named author in his recent paper (Wa̧sowicz in Aequ Math 94(5):887–898, 2020).

title: Remarks on the functional equationf(x+y−xy)+f(xy)=f(x)+f(y)
Some remarks on a functional equation characterizing the root

abstract: Abstract The main result of the present paper is about the solutions of the functional equation $$\begin{aligned} F\Big (\frac{x+y}{2}\Big )+f_1(x)+f_2(y)=G(g_1(x)+g_2(y)),\quad x,y\in I, \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mtable><mml:mtr><mml:mtd><mml:mrow><mml:mi>F</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mfrac><mml:mrow><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi></mml:mrow><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:mfrac><mml:mrow><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mi>G</mml:mi><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mspace /><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>∈</mml:mo><mml:mi>I</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:mtd></mml:mtr></mml:mtable></mml:mrow></mml:math> derived originally, in a natural way, from the invariance problem of generalized weighted quasi-arithmetic means, where $$F,f_1,f_2,g_1,g_2:I\rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>F</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mo>:</mml:mo><mml:mi>I</mml:mi><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi>R</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> and $$G:g_1(I)+g_2(I)\rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>G</mml:mi><mml:mo>:</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>I</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>I</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi>R</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> are the unknown functions assumed to be continuously differentiable with $$0\notin g'_1(I)\cup g'_2(I)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mn>0</mml:mn><mml:mo>∉</mml:mo><mml:msubsup><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msubsup><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>I</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>∪</mml:mo><mml:msubsup><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn><mml:mo>′</mml:mo></mml:msubsup><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>I</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:mrow></mml:math> , and the set I stands for a nonempty open subinterval of $${\mathbb {R}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>R</mml:mi></mml:math> . In addition to these, we will also touch upon solutions not necessarily regular. More precisely, we are going to solve the above equation assuming first that F is affine on I and $$g_1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:math> and $$g_2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:math> are continuous functions strictly monotone in the same sense, and secondly that $$g_1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:math> and $$g_2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msub></mml:math> are invertible affine functions with a common additive part.

title: Finite dimensional varieties over the Heisenberg group
abstract: Abstract Spectral analysis and synthesis studies translation invariant function spaces, so-called varieties over topological groups. The basic building blocks are the finite dimensional varieties. In the commutative case finite dimensional varieties are spanned by exponential polynomials. In non-commutative situations no relevant results exist. In this paper we consider finite dimensional left translation invariant linear spaces of continuous complex valued functions over the Heisenberg group. Using basic knowledge about Lie algebra we describe all left varieties of this type. In particular, it turns out that those function spaces are spanned by exponential polynomials as well.

A note on the Radiant formula and its relations to the sliced Wasserstein distance
abstract: Abstract In this note, we show that the squared Wasserstein distance can be expressed as the average over the sphere of one dimensional Wasserstein distances. We name this new expression for the Wasserstein Distance Radiant Formula . Using this formula, we are able to highlight new connections between the Wasserstein distances and the Sliced Wasserstein distance, an alternative Wasserstein-like distance that is cheaper to compute.

title: Curves that allow the motion of a regular polygon
abstract: Abstract This paper characterizes curves where a regular polygon of either a variable side length or a constant side length is allowed to rotate during k full revolutions while having its vertices on the curve during the motion. A constructive method to generate these curves is given based on the curve described by the polygon centers (centroids) during the motion and some examples are shown. Moreover, if the regular polygon divides the curve perimeter into parts of equal length, it is proved that the curve is either a rotational symmetric curve in the case of a variable side length or a circle otherwise. Finally, in the case of a regular polygon of constant side length rotating along a curve, a simple relation between the algebraic areas of such a curve and the curve of polygon centers is revisited.

title: About Sobolev spaces on fractals: fractal gradians and Laplacians

title: Matrix inequalities between $$f(A)\sigma f(B)$$ and $$A\sigma B$$

title: Semi-classical 2-dimensional Minkowski planes
abstract: Abstract Semi-classical geometries have been investigated in the context of 2-dimensional affine planes, projective planes, Möbius planes and Laguerre planes. Here we deal with the case of 2-dimensional Minkowski planes. Semi-classical 2-dimensional Minkowski planes are obtained by pasting together two halves of the classical real Minkowski plane along two circles or parallel classes. By solving some functional equations for the functions that describe the pasting we determine all semi-classical 2-dimensional Minkowski planes. In contrast to the rich variety of other semi-classical planes there are only very few models of such Minkowski planes.

title: Twisted coefficients on coarse spaces and their corona
abstract:
Abstract To a metric space X we associate a compact topological space $$
u '({X})$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>ν</mml:mi> <mml:mo>′</mml:mo> </mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> called the corona of X . Then a coarse map $$f:Xightarrow Y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> between metric spaces is mapped to a continuous map $$
