Sheaf cohomology assigned to a coarse metric space is preserved and reflected by the corona functor. This work reveals new tools to analyze the Higson corona.

title: General hyperstability criteria for Jensen-type equations
abstract: Abstract We provide two large classes of control functions that ensure the hyperstability of Jensen-type equations on restricted domains. Among other consequences, we obtain improvements on similar results known in the literature for some Aoki–Rassias-type control functions and hyperstability results for some equations whose solutions are Jensen functions compounded with radical-type functions or with trigonometric functions.

title: All solutions to a Schröder type functional equation
Another approach to K-subadditivity
abstract: Abstract In the paper the notion of weakly K -subadditive set-valued maps is introduced in such a way that F is weakly K -superadditive if and only if $$-F$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is weakly K -subadditive. This new definition is a natural generalization of K -subadditive set-valued maps from Jabłońska and Nikodem (Aequ Math 95:1221–1231, 2021), for which opposite set-valued maps need not be K -subadditive. Among others, we prove that every weakly K -subadditive set-valued map which is K –upper bounded on a “large” set has to be locally weakly K -upper bounded and weakly K -lower bounded at every point of the domain. This theorem completes an analogous result for K -subadditive set-valued maps which are weakly K -upper bounded on “large” sets from Jabłońska and Nikodem (Aequ Math 95:1221–1231, 2021).

title: Smooth solutions of a class of iterative functional equations
Spherical and hyperbolic bicentric polygons
On surface of Apollonius of two ellipsoids
abstract: Abstract Apollonius defined the circle as the set of points that have a given ratio $$\mu $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>μ</mml:mi> </mml:math> of distances from two given points, where the ratio is not equal to one. In a more general sense, consider two 0-symmetric, bounded, convex bodies K and $$K'$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>K</mml:mi> <mml:mo>′</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> , which define two norms. Their unit balls are K and $$K'$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>K</mml:mi> <mml:mo>′</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> . The surface of Apollonius is defined as the set of points equidistant from the centres of bodies K and $$K'$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>K</mml:mi> <mml:mo>′</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:math> with respect to the aforementioned norms. In this paper we demonstrate that the surface of Apollonius of two ellipsoids is a quadratic surface. We also examine the circumstances under which this surface becomes a sphere.

title: Asymptotic expansions of the Archimedean compounds
authors: Tomislav Burić; Neven Elezović; Lenka Mihoković

title: Balanced Stirling numbers
Well-posedness for a class of pseudo-differential hyperbolic equations on the torus
authors: Duván Cardona; Julio Delgado; Michael Ruzhansky
abstract: Abstract In this paper we establish the well-posedness of the Cauchy problem for a class of pseudo-differential hyperbolic equations on the torus. The class considered here includes a space-like fractional order Laplacians. By applying the toroidal pseudo-differential calculus we establish regularity estimates, existence and uniqueness in the scale of the standard Sobolev spaces on the torus.

title: Solutions of the functional difference Toda equation from centered Darboux transformation

abstract: We deal with the functional equations $$f(\sigma(y)x + (1 - \sigma(y))y) = \tau(y)f(x) + (1 - \tau(y))f(y)$$ for $${x, y \in [0, \infty)}$$ , $${x \geq y}$$ , where $${f : [0, \infty) \to \mathbb{R}}$$ and $${\sigma, \tau : [0, \infty)\to [0, 1]}$$ ; and $$F(\sigma(y)x + (1 - \sigma(y))y) = \tau(y)F(x) + (1 - \tau(y))F(y)$$ for $${x, y \in \mathcal{C}}$$ , $${x - y \in \mathcal{C}}$$ , where $${\mathcal{C}}$$ is a convex cone in a real linear space, $${F : \mathcal{C} \to \mathbb{R}}$$ and $${\sigma, \tau : \mathcal{C} \to [0, 1]}$$ . We determine the solutions of these equations satisfying some natural regularity assumptions. In this way we generalize the result of J. Aczél and R. D. Luce.

abstract: Using some results on convex and almost convex functions defined on a locally compact Abelian group, we prove a theorem showing a “measurability implies continuity” effect for non-negative solutions of the difference equation $${\varphi(x) = \sum_{i=1}^{k}p_{i}\varphi\left(x+a_{i} \right)}$$ , where $${p_{1}, \ldots, p_{k} \in (0, \infty)}$$ and non-zero elements $${a_{1}, \ldots, a_{k}}$$ of the group are given.

Conditionally δ-midconvex functions
authors: Jacek Chudziak; Jacek Tabor; Józef Tabor
abstract: Let X be a real linear space, V be a nonempty subset of X and δ be a nonnegative real number. A function $${f : V \to \mathbb{R}}$$ is said to be conditionally δ-midconvex provided $${f(\frac{x+y}{2}) \leq \frac{f(x) + f(y)}{2} + \delta}$$ for every $${x, y \in V}$$ such that $${\frac{x + y}{2} \in V}$$ . We show that if V satisfies some reasonable assumptions, then for every bounded from above conditionally δ-midconvex function $${f : V \to \mathbb{R}}$$ the following estimation holds: $${\sup f(V) \leq \sup f(ext \, V) + k (V)\delta}$$ , where ext V denotes the set of all extremal points of V and k(V) is a respective constant depending on V.

Second order iterative functional equations related to a competition equation
abstract: The functional equation related to competition ([2]) $$f\left( \frac{x+y}{1-xy}\right) =\frac{f\left( x\right) +f\left(y\right)} {1+f\left( x\right) f\left( y\right)},\qquad x,y\in\mathbb{R}, xy\neq 1,$$ for y = cx with a fixed c > 0, leads to the equation $$f\left( \frac{\left( 1+c\right) x}{1-cx^{2}}\right) =\frac{f\left(x\right) +f\left( cx\right)} {1+f\left( x\right) f\left( cx\right)},\qquad x\in \mathbb{R}, \left\vert x \right\vert <\frac{1}{\sqrt{c}}.$$ The case c = 1 (a first order iterative functional equation) was treated in [3]. In this paper we consider the case c ≠ 1 (when the equation is of the second order). We show that a function $${f:\mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R},\,f\left( 0\right) =0}$$ , differentiable at the point 0 satisfies this functional equation iff there is a real p such that $${f=\tanh \circ \left( p\tan ^{-1} \right) }$$ which extends the main result of [3].

Stability of functional equations connected with quadrature rules
abstract: We study the stability properties of the equation 0.1 $$F(y) - F(x) = (y - x) \sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}f(\alpha_i x + \beta_{i}y)$$ which is motivated by numerical integration. In Szostok and Wa̧sowicz (Appl Math Lett 24(4):541–544, 2011) the stability of the simplest equation of the type (0.1) was investigated thus the inequality $$\left|F(y) - F(x) - (y - x)f\left(x + y\right)\right| \leq \varepsilon$$ was studied. In the current paper we present a somewhat different approach to the problem of stability of (0.1). Namely, we deal with the inequality $$\left|\frac{F(y) - F(x)}{y - x} - \sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}f(\alpha_{i}x + \beta_{i}y)\right| \leq \varepsilon.$$

abstract: Abstract Let X be a hypergroup, K its compact subhypergroup and assume that ( X , K ) is a Gelfand pair. Connections between finite dimensional varieties and K -polynomials on X are discussed. It is shown that a K -variety on X is finite dimensional if and only if it is spanned by finitely many K -monomials. Next, finite dimensional varieties on affine groups over $${\mathbb {R}}^d$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> , where d is a positive integer are discussed. A complete description of those varieties using partial differential equations is given.

abstract: Abstract Based on a result of de Rham, we give a family of functions solving the Matkowski and Wesołowski problem. This family consists of Hölder continuous functions, and it coincides with the whole family of solutions to the Matkowski and Wesołowski problem found earlier by a different method. Moreover, applying some results due to Hata and Yamaguti and due to Berg and Krüppel, we prove that there are functions solving the Matkowski and Wesołowski problem that are not Hölder continuous.

title: Characterization of t-affine differences and related forms
abstract: Abstract In the present paper we are concerned with the problem of characterization of maps which can be expressed as an affine difference i.e. a map of the form $$\begin{aligned} tf(x)+(1-t)f(y)-f(tx+(1-t)y), \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>t</mml:mi> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>t</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>t</mml:mi> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>t</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> where $$t\in (0,1)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>t</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is a given number. We give a general solution of the functional equation associated with this problem.

title: Stability results and separations theorems
abstract: Abstract The presented work summarizes the relationships between stability results and separation theorems. We prove the equivalence between different types of theorems on separation by an additive map and different types of stability results concerning the stability of the Cauchy functional equation.

title: Note on generalized Archimedes–Borchardt algorithm
abstract: Abstract We investigate convergence and invariance properties of the generalized Archimedes–Borchardt algorithm. The main tool is reducing the problem to an appropriate Gauss iteration process.

title: Means, Milne’s inequality, and quadrilateral area
Volumetric bounds for intersections of congruent balls in Euclidean spaces
Reduction formulas for higher order derivations and a hypergeometric identity
On q-poly-Bernoulli numbers arising from combinatorial interpretations
authors: Beáta Bényi; José Luis Ramírez Arias
abstract: Abstract In this paper we present several natural q -analogues of the poly-Bernoulli numbers arising in combinatorial contexts. We also recall some related analytical results and ask for combinatorial interpretations.

title: Row-summable matrices with application to generalization of Schröder’s and Abel’s functional equations
Complementary means with respect to a nonsymmetric invariant mean
abstract: Abstract It is known that if a bivariate mean K is symmetric, continuous and strictly increasing in each variable, then for every mean M there is a unique mean $$N\,$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>N</mml:mi><mml:mspace /></mml:mrow></mml:math> such that K is invariant with respect to the mean-type mapping $$\left( M,N\right) ,$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mfenced><mml:mi>M</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>N</mml:mi></mml:mfenced><mml:mo>,</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math> which means that $$K\circ \left( M,N\right) =K$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>K</mml:mi><mml:mo>∘</mml:mo><mml:mfenced><mml:mi>M</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>N</mml:mi></mml:mfenced><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mi>K</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> and N is called a K -complementary mean for M (Matkowski in Aequ Math 57(1):87–107, 1999). This paper extends this result for a large class of nonsymmetric means. As an application, the limits of the sequences of iterates of the related mean-type mappings are determined, which allows us to find all continuous solutions of some functional equations.

title: On multiplicative functions additive on Goldbach-type sets
Linear functional equations and their solutions in generalized Orlicz spaces
abstract: Abstract Assume that $$\Omega \subset \mathbb {R}^k$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is an open set, V is a real separable Banach space and $$f_1,\ldots ,f_N :\Omega \rightarrow \Omega $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , $$g_1,\ldots , g_N:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , $$h_0:\Omega \rightarrow V$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>h</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>V</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> are given functions. We are interested in the existence and uniqueness of solutions $$\varphi :\Omega \rightarrow V$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>V</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of the linear equation $$\varphi =\sum _{k=1}^{N}g_k\cdot (\varphi \circ f_k)+h_0$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mo>∑</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>·</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∘</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>h</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> in generalized Orlicz spaces.

title: On linear functional equations modulo $${\mathbb {Z}}$$
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider the condition $$\sum _{i=0}^{n+1}\varphi _i(r_ix+q_iy)\in {\mathbb {Z}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:msubsup><mml:mo>∑</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mi>i</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0</mml:mn></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>n</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:msubsup><mml:msub><mml:mi>φ</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>q</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>∈</mml:mo><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> for real valued functions defined on a linear space V . We derive necessary and sufficient conditions for functions satisfying this condition to be decent in the following sense: there exist functions $$f_i:V\rightarrow {\mathbb {R}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>:</mml:mo><mml:mi>V</mml:mi><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi>R</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> , $$g_i:V\rightarrow {\mathbb {Z}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>:</mml:mo><mml:mi>V</mml:mi><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi>Z</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> such that $$\varphi _i=f_i+g_i$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:msub><mml:mi>φ</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>g</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub></mml:mrow></mml:math> , $$(i=0,\dots ,n+1)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>i</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0</mml:mn><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>n</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>1</mml:mn><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math> and $$\sum _{i=0}^{n+1}f_i(r_ix+q_iy)=0$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:msubsup><mml:mo>∑</mml:mo><mml:mrow><mml:mi>i</mml:mi><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0</mml:mn></mml:mrow><mml:mrow><mml:mi>n</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>1</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:msubsup><mml:msub><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>r</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:msub><mml:mi>q</mml:mi><mml:mi>i</mml:mi></mml:msub><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>0</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math> for all $$x, y\in V$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>∈</mml:mo><mml:mi>V</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> .

title: Quasi-Cauchy quotients and means
abstract: Abstract Let $$I\subset {\mathbb {R}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be an interval that is closed under addition, and $$ k\in {\mathbb {N}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , $$k\ge 2\,$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mspace /> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . For a function $$f:I\rightarrow \left( 0,\infty \right) $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:mfenced> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> such that $$F\left( x\right) :=\frac{f\left( kx\right) }{ kf\left( x\right) }$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> </mml:mfenced> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> </mml:mfenced> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> </mml:mfenced> </mml:mrow> </mml:mfrac> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is invertible in I , the k -variable function $$ M_{f}:I^{k}\rightarrow I,$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>M</mml:mi> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> $$\begin{aligned} M_{f}\left( x_{1},\ldots ,x_{k}\right) :=F^{-1}\left( \frac{f\left( x_{1}+\cdots +x_{k}\right) }{f\left( x_{1}\right) +\cdots +f\left( x_{k}\right) } \right) , \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>M</mml:mi> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mfenced> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:mfenced> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:msup> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:mfenced> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:mfenced> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>k</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:mfenced> </mml:mrow> </mml:mfrac> </mml:mfenced> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is a premean in I , and it is referred to as a quasi Cauchy quotient of the additive type of generator f . Three classes of means of this type generated by the exponential, logarithmic, and power functions, are examined. The suitable quasi Cauchy quotients of the exponential types (for continuous additive, logarithmic, and power functions) are considered. When I is closed under multiplication, the quasi Cauchy quotient means of logarithmic and multiplicative type are studied. The equalities of premeans within each of these classes are discussed and some open problems are proposed.

abstract: We find the solutions $${f,g,h \colon G \to X, \alpha \colon G\to {\mathbb{K}}}$$ of the functional equation $$\sum\limits_{\lambda \in K} f(x+\lambda y)=|K|g(x)+ \alpha (x)h(y),\quad x,y\in G,$$ where (G, +) is an abelian group, K is a finite, abelian subgroup of the automorphism group of G, X is a linear space over the field $${{\mathbb{K}} \in\{{\mathbb{R}},{\mathbb{C}} \}}$$ .

abstract: Abstract In this paper we study the achromatic arboricity of the complete graph. This parameter arises from the arboricity of a graph as the achromatic index arises from the chromatic index. The achromatic arboricity of a graph G , denoted by $$A_{\alpha }(G)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mi>α</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , is the maximum number of colors that can be used to color the edges of G such that every color class induces a forest but any two color classes contain a cycle. In particular, if G is a complete graph we prove that $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{4}n^{\frac{3}{2}}-c_1n \le A_{\alpha }(G)\le \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}n^{\frac{3}{2}}-c_2n \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mn>4</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>c</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mi>α</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:msqrt> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msqrt> </mml:mfrac> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>c</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> where $$c_1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>c</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> and $$c_2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>c</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:math> are constants such that $$0<c_1,c_2<\frac{1}{2}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>c</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>c</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:mfrac> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mfrac> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> .

title: Differentiable solutions of an equation with product of iterates
On monohedral tilings of a regular polygon
abstract: Abstract A tiling of a topological disc by topological discs is called monohedral if all tiles are congruent. Maltby (J Comb Theory Ser A 66:40–52, 1994) characterized the monohedral tilings of a square by three topological discs. Kurusa et al. (Mediterr J Math 17:156, 2020) characterized the monohedral tilings of a circular disc by three topological discs. The aim of this note is to connect these two results by characterizing the monohedral tilings of any regular n -gon with at most three tiles for any $$n \ge 5$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mn>5</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> .

title: Editorial notice
Editorial notice
Pointed redundancy
The Forty-fifth International Symposium on Functional Equations, June 24 – July 1, 2007, Bielsko-Biała, Poland
A note on a functional equation on groups with involutions in two variables
authors: Toine Bogers; Hou Yu Zhao; Shan-Shan Guo

title: On metric stability of set-valued subadditive functions
abstract: Abstract In Shulman (J Funct Anal 263:1468–1484, Theorem 2.2) the author estimated the cardinality of the global image of a subadditive map from a group to an arbitrary power set and applied the result to functional equations of Levi-Civita type (the relations of this result to covering a group by subgroups will be shortly discussed in the present paper). Here we will establish the metric stability of this theorem. Namely it will be shown that if a set-valued map F from a group G to a metric space $$(\mathcal {X}, d)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> satisfies the condition $$\begin{aligned} d \left( F(gh), F(g)\cup F(h)\right) < \delta , \;\; \text {for any }\ g,h\in G \; \text { and some } \delta >0, \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mi>h</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>∪</mml:mo> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>h</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mfenced> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:mi>δ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>for any</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>h</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>and some</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>δ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>></mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and the cardinality of each F ( g ) does not exceed $$n\in \mathbb {N}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , then the set $$F(G):= \cup _{g\in G}F(g)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mo>∪</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> can be covered by $$n(n+3)/2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>/</mml:mo> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> balls of radius $$(3\cdot 6^{n-1}-1)\delta $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> <mml:mo>·</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>6</mml:mn> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mi>δ</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> .

title: Correction to: There is at most one continuous invariant mean
authors: Zoltán Boros; Rezső L. Lovas; Paweł Pasteczka
abstract: A mistake in the formulation of Lemma 1 has been corrected. A preliminary section to the proof of Theorem 1 is added.

title: Deviation from equidistance for one-dimensional sequences
abstract: Abstract For a finite sequence $$(x_i)_{i=1}^N$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> </mml:math> in the unit interval, we introduce the gap ratio function which measures the size of the maximal gap length relative to all other gap lengths. This function (asymptotically) captures a lot of information about the degree of uniformity of the sequence. We discuss connections to the theories of dispersion, discrepancy, pair correlation statistics and covering numbers. Furthermore, we explicitly calculate the gap ratio function for some important classes of uniformly distributed sequences.

title: On quadrature means
abstract: Abstract We observe that every quadrature of numerical integration together with a strictly increasing and continuous function generates a mean and then we study this family of means. We characterize the functions which generate weighted arithmetic means in this way and we show how to obtain comparison type theorems for means generated by different quadratures.

title: The monomial functional equation for connected Lie groups
A generalization of Bohr–Mollerup’s theorem for higher order convex functions: a tutorial
On the Jensen convexity of quasideviation and Bajraktarević means
abstract: Abstract Motivated by the characterization theorem about the Jensen convexity of quasiarithmetic means obtained by the authors in 2021, our main goal is to establish a characterization of the Jensen convexity of quasideviation as well as of Bajraktarević means without any additional and unnatural regularity assumptions .

title: Iterative roots of PM functions extended from the characteristic interval
authors: Veerapazham Murugan; M. Suresh Kumar; Justyna Jarczyk; Witold Jarczyk

title: Explicit forms of invariant means: complementary results to Gauss $$\left( {\mathcal {A}},{\mathcal {G}}\right) $$-theorem and some applications
abstract: Abstract Explicit forms of invariant means for all mean-type mappings generated by the bivariable classical arithmetic, geometric and harmonic means (complementary to the Gauss $$\mathcal {AGM}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>AGM</mml:mi> </mml:math> -theorem) are given. A generalization for higher dimension mean-type mappings as well as two open problems and an application in determining implicit solutions of some functional equations, are presented.

title: Basic sets for some basic functional equations
abstract: Abstract Motivated by the well known fact that any nonzero solution of the fundamental Cauchy functional equation may arbitrarily be prescribed on a Hamel basis, we deal with the following problem: given a functional equation $$\begin{aligned} E_1(\varphi ) = E_2(\varphi ) \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mtable> <mml:mtr> <mml:mtd> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>E</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>E</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> with the unknown function $$\varphi : X \longrightarrow Y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⟶</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , what must the set $$\emptyset \ne Z \subset X$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>∅</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≠</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be like in order to ensure that an arbitrary function $$\varphi _0: Z \longrightarrow Y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⟶</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> admits a unique function $$\varphi : X \longrightarrow Y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⟶</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> solving equation ( $$*$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mrow /> <mml:mo>∗</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> ) and such that $$\varphi _{|_Z} = \varphi _0$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>|</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>Z</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> ; if such a set does exist it is termed to be a basic set. We discuss the problem of existence of basic sets for exponential functions, d’Alembert’s functions, sine functions, Cuculière’s functions and hyperbolic tangent type functions, among others.

title: Almost multiplicative maps with respect to almost associative operations on Banach algebras
abstract: Abstract We prove an Ulam type stability result for a non-associative version of the multiplicativity equation, that is, $$T(xy)=\Psi (T(x),T(y))$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>T</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ψ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>T</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>T</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , where T is a unital bounded operator acting from an amenable Banach algebra to a dual Banach algebra.

title: On a functional equation on groups in two variables
Mountain-climbing constructions for piecewise monotone functions
Spatial graphoids
authors: Neslihan Gügümcü; Louis H. Kauffman; Puttipong Pongtanapaisan

title: Iterated rascal triangles
authors: J. D. Gregory; Brandt Kronholm; Jacob A. White

title: Some study of the approximate Birkhoff orthogonality and orthogonality of bounded linear operators
authors: Huayou Xie; Chuanjiang Zhou; Yongjin Li

title: Recent progress on minimal hypersurfaces with cylindrical tangent cones
Refinements of discrete and integral Jensen inequalities with Jensen’s gap
abstract: Abstract Motivated by a paper of Dragomir, we give new refinements for both discrete and integral Jensen inequalities using the Jensen’s gap. As applications, we give refinements of various inequalities verifiable by Jensen’s inequality. Topics covered: norms, quasi-arithmetic means, Hölder’s inequality and f -divergences in information theory.

title: On the functional equation $$\hbox {f}(\hbox {x}+\hbox {y})=\hbox {g}(\hbox {xy})$$
authors: Péter Erdei; Tamás Glavosits; Attila Házy
abstract: Abstract The functional equation $$f(x+y)=g(xy)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is investigated with unknown functions $$f:A+A\rightarrow Y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , $$g:A\cdot A\rightarrow Y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>·</mml:mo> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> in the following cases: $$A:=\left]\alpha ,\beta \right[\subseteq \mathbb {F}_{+}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mi>α</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>β</mml:mi> </mml:mfenced> <mml:mo>⊆</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> where $$\mathbb {F}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> </mml:math> is an Archimedean ordered field; A is the set of all positive integers; A is the set of all positive dyadic rational numbers. The set Y is an arbitrarily fixed (infinite) set. The main result of the paper shows that there exists a set $$A\subseteq \mathbb {R}_{+}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊆</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> that is closed under addition and multiplication and there exist functions f , $$g:A\rightarrow Y$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Y</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> which satisfy the equation $$f(x+y)=g(xy)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for all $$x,y\in A$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>y</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> such that the range of the function f is infinite. Finally, some application of the above results is also given.

title: A classification of non-monotonicity height for piecewise monotone functions (I): increasing case
authors: Kui Wu; Lin Li; Wei Song

title: Functional equations stemming from ‘scientific laws’
abstract: Abstract Functional equations involving certain generalized forms of the so-called ‘laws of sciences’ are considered. The resolution of these equations is linked to the concept of comparison meaningfulness that appears in measurement theory and dimension theory. The results obtained are stated without assuming any topological requirement.

title: Characterizations of Jordan *-isomorphisms of $$C^*$$-algebras by Schatten p-norm of Kubo–Ando means
authors: Kaixuan Li; Lei Li; Zheng Shi; Liguang Wang

title: The 59th International Symposium on Functional Equations Hotel Aurum, Hajdúszoboszló (Hungary), June 18–25, 2023
Maciej Sablik
abstract: I have known Maciej Sablik for almost half a century; I first met him at the Institute of Mathematics of the Silesian University of Katowice when he attended the so called Kuczma's Tuesday Seminar as a student.He was born in Chorzów (some years ago) but ever since he has lived in Katowice.He completed his education here: the primary school (no.37), followed by the high school named after Nicholas Copernicus, whence after graduation he began studying mathematics at the Faculty of Mathematics, Physics and Chemistry of the Silesian University of Katowice.It is remarkable that all these institutions at that time were situated in the building what is now the Silesian Priests Seminar.Not very far there is also a cemetery, so it seemed that he would live his life in a space of a square mile.However, the mathematics institute was transferred to the Bankowa

title: László Székelyhidi
abstract: Székelyhidi was born on 11 May 1952 in Budapest, Hungary.He completed his primary school studies in the western part of Hungary, in Mosonmagyaróvár and Hegyeshalom.After primary school, he continued his studies at Temesvári Pelbárt Ferences Gimnázium (a Franciscan High School) in Esztergom.The years he spent there-as he would often tell us-had a decisive impact on his life.With some of his classmates, he established a band there playing beat music, which at the time was very popular in Hungary as well.His interest in mathematics also became deeper during his high school years.Based on these experiences, he had two ideas regarding his possible future career.One of them was to do something related to music: he was considering becoming an audio engineer.

title: Remarks on Wright-convex functions
abstract: Abstract In the present paper we prove a generalized version of the famous decomposition theorem of Ng. We also focus on the problem posed by Zsolt Páles concerning the Wright-convex functions.

title: On the state of the second part of Hilbert’s fifth problem
abstract: Abstract In the second part of his fifth problem Hilbert asks for functional equations “In how far are the assertions which we can make in the case of differentiable functions true under proper modifications without this assumption.” In the case of the general functional equation $$\begin{aligned} f(x)=h\Bigl (x,y,\bigl (g_1(x,y)\bigr ),\ldots ,\bigl (g_n(x,y)\bigr )\Bigr ) The natural conditions imply that the dimension of x cannot be larger than the dimension of y . If we remove this condition, then we have to add another condition. In this survey paper a new problem for this second case is formulated and results are summarised for both cases.

title: Iterated joining means
abstract: Using a simple dynamical system generated by means M and N which are considered on adjacent intervals, we show how to find their joints, that is means extending both M and N. The procedure of joining is a local version of that presented in Jarczyk (Publ. Math. Debr. 91:235–246, 2017). Among joints are those semiconjugating some functions defined by the use of the so-called marginal functions of M and N.

title: On a quadratic difference assuming three values
On multiplicatively-additive iteration groups
abstract: Define on the set $$G:=\mathbb R^+\times \mathbb R$$ the operation $$(t,a)*(s,b)=(ts,tb+a)$$ . $$(G,*)$$ is a non-commutative group with the neutral element (1, 0). We consider a non-commutative translation equation $$F(\eta ,F(\xi ,x))=F(\eta *\xi ,x)$$ , $$\eta , \xi \in G$$ , $$x\in I$$ , $$F(1,0)=\mathrm{id}$$ , where I is an open interval and $$F:G\times I\rightarrow I$$ is a continuous mapping. This equation can be written in the form: $$F((t,a),F((s,b),x))=F((ts,tb+a),x)$$ , $$ t,s \in \mathbb R^+$$ , $$x\in I$$ . For $$t=1$$ the family $$\{F(t,a)\}$$ defines an additive iteration group, however for $$a=0$$ it defines a multiplicative iteration group. We show that if F(t, 0) for some $$t\ne 1$$ has exactly one fixed point $$x_t$$ , $$(F(t,0)-\mathrm{id})(x_t-\mathrm{id})\ge 0$$ and for an $$a>0 $$ $$F(1,a)>\mathrm {id}$$ , then there exists a unique homeomorphism $$\varphi :I\rightarrow \mathbb R$$ such that $$F((s,b),x)=\varphi ^{-1}(s\varphi (x)+b)$$ for $$s\in \mathbb R^+$$ and $$b\in \mathbb R$$ .

Karol Baron: a little bit about him on his 70th birthday
abstract: WJ:For the first time I met Dr. Karol Baron at the very beginning of October 1975, when I was studying mathematics at the Faculty of Mathematics, Physics and Chemistry at the University of Silesia in Katowice, Poland, and he was giving classes on the theory of real functions there.Following the lecture of Professor Marek Kuczma he made use of the famous monograph [24] by Roman Sikorski, another distinguished Polish mathematician.That book contains a great number of nice and highly non-trivial exercises and the contact with them and the numerous attempts (not often successfull!) to solve them were one of my very first experiences with great mathematics.His calm questions "if somebody would like to present a solution of a problem" really stimulated us, a group of a few students.One semester later I was already invited by Professor Kuczma to join the Seminar on functional equations led by him.I am almost sure about the crucial role of Karol Baron while going about that business.It was the time of his long hair, cigarettes or a pipe, and sometimes even a barber could have a job with him.JM: I met Doc.Karol Baron as a third-year master's degree student in 1984, when he was giving (together with prof.Marek Kuczma) a pro-seminar entitled Functional equations in a single variable.In the same academic year, I participated in his lecture on the theory of probability.I saw for the first time that a lecture could be like a mathematical book.It was split into smaller It is a great pleasure for us to write a few sentences about Karol Baron, our teacher, master, colleague and then also a friend of us.Of course such a sentence may be treated as a polite but very trivial one which could begin almost every tribute to a distinguished colleague.In this case, however, there is no doubt that we are completely heart-to-heart: mature enough not to do mind opinions of our previous boss and supervisor.We both (WJ and JM) have different experiences when thinking about Karol, so the story runs in two parallel lines.

title: The $$\varvec{r}$$-alternating permutations
On the Kesava Menon norm of semimultiplicative functions
abstract: The Kesava Menon norm of an arithmetical function f is defined by $$N(f)(n) = (f*\lambda f)(n^2)$$, where $$*$$ denotes the Dirichlet convolution and $$\lambda $$ denotes Liouville’s function. The mth power Kesava Menon norm of f is defined inductively by $$N^0(f) = f$$, $$N^m(f)=N\big (N^{m-1}(f)\big )$$, $$m=1,2,\ldots $$ In this paper we prove that the mth power Kesava Menon norm of a semimultiplicative function is semimultiplicative and that the mth power Kesava Menon norm distributes over the Dirichlet convolution of semimultiplicative functions. In addition we show that the mth power Kesava Menon norm of a rational arithmetical function of degree (r, s) is a rational arithmetical function of the same degree.

title: Means of iterates
abstract: We determine continuous bijections f, acting on a real interval into itself, whose k-fold iterate is the quasi-arithmetic mean of all its subsequent iterates from $$f^0$$ up to $$f^n$$ (where $$0\leqslant k\leqslant n$$ ). Namely, we prove that if at most one of the numbers k, n is odd, then such functions consist of at most three affine pieces.

On a class of abstract convex cone valued functional equations
abstract: We present an approach to solving a number of functional equations for functions with values in abstract convex cones. Such cones seem to be good generalizations of, e.g., families of nonempty compact and convex subsets or nonempty closed, bounded and convex subsets of a normed space. Moreover, we study some related stability problems.

abstract: Abstract In this paper we consider a generalization of d’Alembert’s equation and Wilson’s equation on commutative semigroups using only the semigroup operation, ie. we consider the functional equation $$\begin{aligned}&h(x+2y)+h(x)=2f(y)h(x+y),\ x,y\in S, \end{aligned}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mtable><mml:mtr><mml:mtd /><mml:mtd><mml:mrow><mml:mi>h</mml:mi><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mn>2</mml:mn><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mi>h</mml:mi><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mo>=</mml:mo><mml:mn>2</mml:mn><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mi>h</mml:mi><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>)</mml:mo><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mspace /><mml:mi>x</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>y</mml:mi><mml:mo>∈</mml:mo><mml:mi>S</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:mtd></mml:mtr></mml:mtable></mml:mrow></mml:math> where $$f,h:S\rightarrow \mathbb {K}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mi>f</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mi>h</mml:mi><mml:mo>:</mml:mo><mml:mi>S</mml:mi><mml:mo>→</mml:mo><mml:mi>K</mml:mi></mml:mrow></mml:math> , $$(S,+)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mo>(</mml:mo><mml:mi>S</mml:mi><mml:mo>,</mml:mo><mml:mo>+</mml:mo><mml:mo>)</mml:mo></mml:mrow></mml:math> is a commutative semigroup, $$\mathbb {K}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>K</mml:mi></mml:math> is a quadratically closed field, $$\text {char}\,\mathbb {K}\ne 2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mrow><mml:mtext>char</mml:mtext><mml:mspace /><mml:mi>K</mml:mi><mml:mo>≠</mml:mo><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:mrow></mml:math> .

Maps stemming from the functional calculus that transform a Kubo–Ando mean into another
abstract: Abstract In this paper, we investigate maps on sets of positive operators which are induced by the continuous functional calculus and transform a Kubo–Ando mean $$\sigma $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>σ</mml:mi></mml:math> into another $$\tau $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>τ</mml:mi></mml:math> . We establish that under quite mild conditions, a mapping $$\phi $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>ϕ</mml:mi></mml:math> can have this property only in the trivial case, i.e. when $$\sigma $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>σ</mml:mi></mml:math> and $$\tau $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>τ</mml:mi></mml:math> are nontrivial weighted harmonic means and $$\phi $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>ϕ</mml:mi></mml:math> stems from a function which is a constant multiple of the generating function of such a mean. In the setting where exactly one of $$\sigma $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>σ</mml:mi></mml:math> and $$\tau $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>τ</mml:mi></mml:math> is a weighted arithmetic mean, we show that under fairly weak assumptions, the mentioned transformer property never holds. Finally, when both of $$\sigma $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>σ</mml:mi></mml:math> and $$\tau $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>τ</mml:mi></mml:math> are such a mean, it turns out that the latter property is only satisfied in the trivial case, i.e. for maps induced by affine functions.

Convexity properties of functions defined on metric Abelian groups
abstract: The notions of quasiconvexity, Wright convexity and convexity for functions defined on a metric Abelian group are introduced. Various characterizations of such functions, the structural properties of the functions classes so obtained are established and several well-known results are extended to this new setting.

abstract: Abstract Let $$(\Omega , \mathcal {F}, \mathbb {P})$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be a probability space and let $$\alpha , \beta : \mathcal {F} \rightarrow ~\mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>α</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>β</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> be random variables. We provide sufficient conditions under which every bounded continuous solution $$\varphi : \mathbb {R} \rightarrow \mathbb {R}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of the equation $$ \varphi (x) = \int _{ \Omega } \varphi \left( \alpha (\omega ) (x-\beta (\omega ))\right) \mathbb {P}(d\omega )$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mo>∫</mml:mo> <mml:mi>Ω</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>φ</mml:mi> <mml:mfenced> <mml:mi>α</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>β</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mfenced> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is constant. We also show that any non-constant bounded continuous solution of the above equation has to be oscillating at infinity.

title: Symmetric spectral synthesis
abstract: Abstract According to the famous and pioneering result of Laurent Schwartz, any closed translation invariant linear space of continuous functions on the reals is synthesizable from its exponential monomials. Due to a result of D. I. Gurevič there is no straightforward extension of this result to higher dimensions. Following Székelyhidi (Acta Math Hungar 153(1):120–142, 2017), with the aid of Gelfand pairs and K -spherical functions, K -synthesizability of K -varieties can be described. In this paper we contribute to this direction in the special case when K is the symmetric group of order d .

On the critical exponents of generalized ballot sequences in three dimensions and large tandem walks
abstract: We answer some questions on the asymptotics of ballot walks raised in [S. B. Ekhad and D. Zeilberger, April 2021] and prove that these models are not D-finite. This short note demonstrates how the powerful tools developed in the last decades on lattice paths in convex cones help us to answer some challenging problems that were out of reach for a long time. On the way we generalize tandem walks to the family of large tandem walks whose steps are of arbitrary length and map them bijectively to a generalization of ballot walks in three dimensions.

title: Random packings and coverings in random trees
Properties of Motzkin triangle and t-generalized Motzkin sequences
abstract: Abstract We consider the Motzkin triangle as the zero-free part of a well-defined plane array. The right diagonal leg of the triangle is the Motzkin sequence, which satisfies a second order linear recurrence with linear polynomial coefficients. We extend this relation to the parallel diagonals to the line of Motzkin sequence. More generally, we prove the existence of a recursive formula for the formation of three arbitrary elements in the triangle, and construct the corresponding formulae for three connected entries, among them diagonal triples, of twenty possible formations. These recursive formulae have bivariate polynomial coefficients of higher order. We describe the columns of the Motzkin triangle as polynomial values, and reveal nice non-trivial factorization properties of these polynomials. The results essentially depend on an initially derived recursive rule of three consecutive horizontal elements provided by the definition of the triangle, and on a construction method which creates recurrence rules for other structures.

<mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:mtd> </mml:mtr> </mml:mtable> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> can be represented as the composition of a strictly monotone, continuous function and a linear functional as well. Applying the latter theorem, we give a characterization of Cobb–Douglas type utility functions.

title: On a multiplicative distribution of functions in complex plane
abstract: Abstract In the paper there are two kinds of functional symmetry considered, i.e., (1)-power symmetry and $$(-1)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> -power symmetry, in a rich subfamily $$\mathcal {B}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>B</mml:mi> </mml:math> of the family of all complex valued functions on a symmetric set $$\mathcal {G}\subset \mathbb {C}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . The first one defines the values $$f(-z)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>z</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> as identical with f ( z ) and the other as the inverse of the f ( z ) in $$\mathcal {G}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:math> . The announced notions allow a unique decomposition of functions $$f\in \mathcal {B}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>B</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> into a product of two factors $$f_{1},f_{-1}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> having the (1)- and the $$(-1)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> -power symmetry property, respectively. In the paper there are also given examples of such partitions $$f=f_{1}\cdot f_{-1}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>·</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , for various $$f\in \mathcal {B},$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>B</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> a solution of the problem of invariance of the above functional symmetries with respect to some one- and two-argument function operations and two applications of the mentioned function decomposition.

In each of these three cases a complete solution is given.

title: On Wendel’s equality for intersections of balls
authors: Ferenc Fodor; Nicolás A. Montenegro Pinzón; Viktor Vígh
abstract: Abstract We study the analogue of Wendel’s equality in random polytope models in which the hull of the random points is formed by intersections of congruent balls, called the spindle (or hyper-) convex hull. According to the classical identity of Wendel the probability that the origin is contained in the (linear) convex hull of n i.i.d. random points distributed according to an origin symmetric probability distribution in the d -dimensional Euclidean space $$\mathbb {R}^{d}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> that assigns measure zero to hyperplanes is a constant depending only on n and d . While in the classical convex case one gets nonzero probabilities only for $$n\ge d+1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> points in $$\mathbb {R}^{d}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>d</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> , for the spindle convex hull this happens for all $$n\ge 2$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . We study this question for the uniform and normally distributed random models.

Eri Jabotinsky, mathematician and politician: a short biography
abstract: Abstract Despite the fact that Eri Jabotinsky (1910–1969) published only few (i.e. fourteen) mathematical papers, some of them had a remarkable influence in iteration theory. But also his life was remakable. Eri was the son of the famous Zionist Revisionist leader Vladimir Ze’ev Jabotinsky. Eri Jabotinsky was active in the Zionist movement and later as parlamentarian in the Knesset. Here we give an outline of his live and a complete list of his publications.

abstract: Abstract The classes of band-dominated operators and the subclass of operators in the Wiener algebra $${\mathcal {W}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>W</mml:mi> </mml:math> are known to be inverse closed. This paper studies and extends partially known results of that type for one-sided and generalized invertibility. Furthermore, for the operators in the Wiener algebra $${\mathcal {W}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>W</mml:mi> </mml:math> invertibility, the Fredholm property and the Fredholm index are known to be independent of the underlying space $$l^p$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mi>l</mml:mi> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> , $$1\le p\le \infty $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . Here this is completed by the observation that even the kernel and a suitable direct complement of the range as well as generalized inverses of operators in $${\mathcal {W}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>W</mml:mi> </mml:math> are invariant w.r.t. p .

title: The solvability cardinal of the class of polynomials
abstract: Abstract Let G be an Abelian group, and let $${{\mathbb {C}}}^G$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> denote the set of complex valued functions defined on G . A map $$D: {{\mathbb {C}}}^G \rightarrow {{\mathbb {C}}}^G$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>D</mml:mi> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>→</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is a difference operator, if there are complex numbers $$a_i$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:math> and elements $$b_i \in G$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>b</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> $$(i=1,\ldots , n)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> such that $$(Df)(x)=\sum _{i=1}^n a_i f(x+b_i)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>D</mml:mi> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msubsup> <mml:mo>∑</mml:mo> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msubsup> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>b</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for every $$f\in {{\mathbb {C}}}^G $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> and $$x\in G$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . By a system of difference equations we mean a set of equations $$\{ D_i f=g_i : i\in I\}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>{</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>D</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mi>f</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>:</mml:mo> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> <mml:mo>}</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , where I is an arbitrary set of indices, $$D_i$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>D</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:math> is a difference operator and $$g_i \in {{\mathbb {C}}}^G$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>g</mml:mi> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is a given function for every $$i\in I$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>i</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>I</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , and f is the unknown function. The solvability cardinal $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathcal {F}}})$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> of a class of functions $${{\mathcal {F}}} \subset {{\mathbb {C}}}^G$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>⊂</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is the smallest cardinal number $$\kappa $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>κ</mml:mi> </mml:math> with the following property: whenever S is a system of difference equations on G such that each subsystem of S of cardinality $$<\kappa $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:mi>κ</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> has a solution in $${{\mathcal {F}}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> </mml:math> , then S itself has a solution in $${{\mathcal {F}}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> </mml:math> . The behaviour of $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathcal {F}}})$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>F</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is rather erratic, even for classes of functions defined on $${{\mathbb {R}}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:math> . For example, $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathbb {C}}}[x])=3$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , but $$\mathrm{sc} \,({\mathcal {TP}}) =\omega _1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>TP</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , where $${\mathcal {TP}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>TP</mml:mi> </mml:math> is the set of trigonometric polynomials; $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathbb {C}}}^{{\mathbb {R}}})=\omega $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , but $$\mathrm{sc} \,({\mathcal {DF}}) =(2^\omega )^+$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>DF</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> </mml:msup> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , where $${\mathcal {DF}}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>DF</mml:mi> </mml:math> is the set of functions having the Darboux property. Our aim is to determine or to estimate the solvability cardinal of the class of polynomials defined on $${{{\mathbb {R}}}}^n$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:math> , on normed linear spaces and, in general, on topological Abelian groups. Let $${{\mathcal {P}}}_G$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msub> </mml:math> denote the class of polynomials defined on the group G . After presenting some general estimates we prove that $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathbb {C}}}[x_1 ,\ldots ,x_n ])=\omega $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> if $$2\le n<\infty $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , and $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathcal {P}}}_X)=\omega _1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>X</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> if X is a normed linear space of infinite dimension. For discrete Abelian groups we show that $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathcal {P}}}_G)=3$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mn>3</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> if $$r_0 (G)\le 1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathcal {P}}}_G)=\omega $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> if $$2\le r_0 (G)<\infty $$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo><</mml:mo> <mml:mi>∞</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> , and $$\mathrm{sc} \,({{\mathcal {P}}}_G)\ge \omega _1$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>sc</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>P</mml:mi> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> <mml:mo>≥</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>ω</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> if $$r_0 (G)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> is infinite, where $$r_0 (G)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>r</mml:mi> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>G</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> denotes the torsion free rank of G . The solvability of systems of difference equations is closely connected to the existence of projections of function classes commuting with translations (see Theorem 7.1). As an application we construct a projection from $${{\mathbb {C}}}^{{{{\mathbb {R}}}}^n}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>R</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msup> </mml:msup> </mml:math> onto $${{\mathbb {C}}}[x_1 ,\ldots ,x_n ]$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>C</mml:mi> <mml:mo>[</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mn>1</mml:mn> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>…</mml:mo> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:msub> <mml:mi>x</mml:mi> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> </mml:msub> <mml:mo>]</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> commuting with translations by vectors having rational coordinates (Theorem 7.4).

title: Correction to: Kadec-Klee property in Musielak-Orlicz function spaces equipped with the Orlicz norm
Numerical semigroups bounded by the translation of a plane monoid
authors: M. A. Moreno-Frías; J. C. Rosales
abstract: Abstract Let $$\mathbb {N}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:math> be the set of nonnegative integer numbers. A plane monoid is a submonoid of $$(\mathbb {N}^2,+)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:msup> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:msup> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . Let M be a plane monoid and $$p,q\in \mathbb {N}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>q</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . We will say that an integer number n is M ( p , q )- bounded if there is $$(a,b)\in M$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>b</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>M</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> such that $$a+p\le n \le b-q$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>a</mml:mi> <mml:mo>+</mml:mo> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>≤</mml:mo> <mml:mi>b</mml:mi> <mml:mo>-</mml:mo> <mml:mi>q</mml:mi> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> . We will denote by $${\mathrm A}(M(p,q))=\{n\in \mathbb {N}\mid n \text { is } M(p,q)\text {-bounded}\}.$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>M</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>q</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mo>{</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∈</mml:mo> <mml:mi>N</mml:mi> <mml:mo>∣</mml:mo> <mml:mi>n</mml:mi> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mtext>is</mml:mtext> <mml:mspace /> <mml:mi>M</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>q</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mtext>-bounded</mml:mtext> <mml:mo>}</mml:mo> <mml:mo>.</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> An $$\mathcal {A}(p,q)$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>q</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> - semigroup is a numerical semigroup S such that $$S= {\mathrm A}(M(p,q))\cup \{0\}$$ <mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mml:mrow> <mml:mi>S</mml:mi> <mml:mo>=</mml:mo> <mml:mi>A</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>M</mml:mi> <mml:mo>(</mml:mo> <mml:mi>p</mml:mi> <mml:mo>,</mml:mo> <mml:mi>q</mml:mi> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>)</mml:mo> <mml:mo>∪</mml:mo> <mml:mo>{</mml:mo> <mml:mn>0</mml:mn> <mml:mo>}</mml:mo> </mml:mrow> </mml:math> for some plane monoid M . In this work we will study these kinds of numerical semigroups.

title: The cosine functional equation for nilpotent groups. (Short Communication).
Interview with Ludwig Reich
abstract: Abstract On the occasion of his 80th birthday, Ludwig Reich, editor-in-chief of Aequationes Mathematicae from 1996 to 2008, gave an interview conducted via Zoom. This paper presents his answers to several questions regarding his education and academic life.
